fields.description: At some point Bamboo thought a backup operation failed and reports to inspect the logs.  I did inspect the logs didn't see any errors... but regardless there appears to be no way to acknowledge and dismiss the error banner displayed on all pages.
fields.summary: Unable to dismiss "Bamboo failed to run the backup" message

fields.description:
Currently there is no easy way to get a list of users who need to be notified for any given Chain. You can get a list of Transports, but this isn't quite the same thing. 

We need something like this for Workday, and have to use multiple instanceof's to reproduce the inner workings of each of the Recipients. Most of this logic already exists, but isn't exposed.
fields.summary: Add getUsernames to NotificationRecipient API

fields.description:
On this page:

http://www.atlassian.com/software/bamboo/overview

Clicking the "Bamboo Documentation" link, takes me to:

http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Bamboo+Documentation

Which is a "Page Not Found" in Confluence.  I know which page to visit, though it strikes me as odd that the documentation link on the product page of your website takes me to a page w/ "Page Not Found".  Probably better if you want to show multiple versions of bamboo documentation, to have this page be a _real_ page with links to each versions documentation space.
fields.summary: Documentation link on website takes me to a not found page in confluence

fields.description:
The http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BAMBOO/Creating+a+Custom+Elastic+Image page has some confusing information in it (not just the general content either, since the topic is complex).  

For example, the section 5.3.2 shows a wget command to fetch version 1.0 of the image, however checking the repository I see that 1.7 is the latest version.  Is the documentation here to download version 1.0 accurate/correct?

The example to unzip the downloaded item is also incorrect.  Its missing the version number.

Based on these 2 trivial documentation errors I'm highly suspicious of the correctness of this entire document.

As mentioned early on this page, this is not a trivial procedure, and with invalid/inaccurate details/examples it becomes only that much more complex for a user to follow.

Can we get the elastic bamboo documentation updated so that its accurate please?
fields.summary: Docs for creating custom elastic image outdated?

fields.description:
The default image configurations contain capability configurations which are not valid.

For example, There is a Maven 3.0.2 capability pointing at /opt/maven-3.0.2, though the image does not have a 3.0.3 maven installed. There is a /opt/maven-3.0 which points to /opt/apache-maven-3.0.3 however.

I've not checked all of the capability configurations for all default images, could be others which are incorrect too.
fields.summary: Elastic agent configuration capabilities are in correct

fields.description:
The "Environment Variables" example on the "Maven 3.x Configuration" task shows JAVA_OPTS instead of MAVEN_OPTS.

While its valid to set JAVA_OPTS, in the context of a Maven builder, this value is meaningless.  The mvn[.bat] scripts use MAVEN_OPTS not JAVA_OPTS to configure the options for the Java VM.
fields.summary: UI for Maven builder shows example using JAVA_OPTS instead of MAVEN_OPTS

fields.summary: Investigate reason for bad sql grammar exception on Oracle

fields.description:
For the final merges not to fail, no commit can hit the branch you're pushing to.

Given our concurrent builds control does not guarantee this, it's not really possible to configure Bamboo in such a way to enforce it to work effectively

We need the ability to set concurrency control across all branches.
fields.summary: Gatekeeper with push requires the commits into that repository to be serialized

fields.description:
CrowdClient, from Crowd 2.4 onwards, lets clients check for changes to groups and users through the REST API. This is used for incremental updates, but simply using it to detect when nothing has changed is also an improvement.

# Before fetching users and groups attempt to {{getCurrentEventToken}}
# If the token is available, store it along with the cached data
# On next synchronisation, attempt to get the token first
# If it's identical to the cached token then use the current cached data without change

This will make synchronisation slightly slower in the general case (one extra call) but far quicker in the case that nothing has changed.
fields.summary: Use getCurrentEventToken when synchronising users with Crowd

fields.description:
Bamboo introduced shared source repositories. These allow us to pre-configure the SVN settings without sending a password around.

I would like to add a path to allow a build plan to only checkout a certain part of the repository.
Currently we maintain several svn repos. We create one shared repo for every svn repo. And the developers create plans as they like. But using shared source repos now causes every build plan to checkout the whole svn repo. This is a bit space consuming.
Currently the build task defines a subfolder where the build runs (which is ok). But if the build plan would allow to specify a certain path for the working copy we would save quite some space.
fields.summary: Add support for sparse checkouts
devenvrunner.bat can't handle target name with spaces if it doesn't contain pipe character

fields.description:
Currently the REST APIs provide a way to pull 'last X results' (max 25) but there isn't a way to specify the last successful build. This is an issue if the last successful build was more than 25 builds ago.

*Workaround:*
An alternative would be to use the [Pre/Post Plugin|https://plugins.atlassian.com/plugin/details/5581] to label the successful builds and then call one of the following resources in order to filter what build numbers have the label:

* Build Service — Specific Project
* Build Service — All Builds
fields.summary: Allow REST APIs to return the latest Successful build for a Plan

fields.description: It could be as simple as sending a message causing System.exit (after the current build is finished) to the agents upon upgrade.
fields.summary: Upgrading a plugin should propagate to agents

fields.description:
The default Trigger condition : *Only run Build if other Plans are currently passing* is not respected.

I setup a manual build strategy with a trigger condition pointing to a top level plan - I made sure the last build on the other plan had failed and then requested a build on the current plan. The plan still gets executed without checking the other plan status.
fields.summary: Conditional Build Triggers are not respected with manual builds
MsTest Parser should parse description tag in testcase result details

fields.description:
Bamboo allow to manually launch Plan individually.
Plan can be grouped by 'Projets'. It should be possible to launch the building of all the plans contained inside a project, handling dependency and all.

Currently, the only way to manually compile all plans inside a project is to launch each one individually. This can be tedious and error prone when there are many one and there's no dependency management: You have to know the order in which you want to launch them.
fields.summary: Build All Plans associated to a Project

fields.description:
If a plan is set to run at a regular time interval rather than being triggered by repository polling, and if commit isolation is turned on for that plan, you will get a not very useful behavior: it'll wait for the specified interval, and then do exactly one build for the changeset immediately following the last build. That is, if the build runs every 24 hours, it'll build r100000 today, r100001 tomorrow, etc. On a project under active development this means it'll never catch up.

Of course it doesn't make sense to configure it this way on purpose, but it can easily happen if you decide to split off some jobs from your main plan into a new one that runs less often, and you clone the plan without changing the isolation setting. I think Bamboo should disallow this combination of settings, or at least strongly warn you about it; I can't imagine that anyone would really want this behavior.

We ran into this with the UPM builds on BEAC. See for instance [UPM-TRUNKOP-7|https://bamboo.extranet.atlassian.com/browse/UPM-TRUNKOP-7] and the ones following that. By the time we figured it out, it was running more than a week behind.
fields.summary: Commit isolation makes no sense for a scheduled build

fields.description:
There is no reason why we can't allow plugins to send messages to their server side counter-parts.  All they need is a way to inject the BambooAgentMessageSender and create their own messages.

Technically it is possible.  But the experience could be improved. 
* The MessageSender bean is funky - this should be injectable (with a decent name) just like any other component
* In Bamboo we have the ability to define a server version of a class and a remote version of a class.  Which makes it handy to define different behaviours based on where you are (message sending doesn't work locally)
* Or, Stick some nice "Am I On A Remote Agent?" method somewhere -> the AgentContext looks like a nice spot...
fields.summary: Improvements for plugins to use our agent messaging infrastructure

fields.description:
When cloning an existing Plan, you need to specify a new Plan Key, however the Job keys are copied from the cloned plan and can not be edited later.  This can lead to confusingly named URI's for the jobs and tasks of the new plan, as they contain a concatenation of the new plan and old job key, if your job key is specific to the cloned plan's project.

The only way to fix this situation is by cloning the individual jobs again, which may defeat the purpose of cloning a plan,

It would be nice to be able to specify new job keys when cloning a plan, or to be able to easily modify them later without having to delete and recreate the jobs.

Thanks.
fields.summary: Add ability to specify job keys when cloning plan

fields.summary: Error when trying to add labels to a plan using the plan admin account (not Global Admin)

fields.description:
I have a number of jobs that do exactly the same build except for 1 param to mvn changing - the test group to be run.
In all other respects the jobs are identical.

I would like to define the job once and just use the definition N times just providing the parameter for the test group.

I know I can clone the job to create a similar one, but when I want to change some param like adding new Artifact definition I need to do it repeatedly for each and every job in the stage.
It is also quite easy to get things messed up, like running "group-2" both in "Group 2" and "Group 4" due to small mistake in clicking.
fields.summary: Job templates
Change the Branch Name and Repository ID field label to Display Name
Adding out a second copy of the same repository in a Checkout Task prevents you from setting its checkout dir

fields.description:
.I like the Shared Repository functionality - it solves one of the pains.

I would love to have similar functionality for credentials.

We have multiple repositories on BitBucket that I would actually like to be accessible from Bamboo.
Current solution that we have is set up a dedicated user, invite it to the repository, ask the guy who created the user what the private key/password is and create new repository.

It would be much easier and straightforward if I could just define those credentials globally and select them when configuring the repository.

The security implications would be basicly the same as for shared repository (ok, now I would be able to access any repository instead of just the ones defined as Shared)
fields.summary: Shared credentials as extension to shared repositories concept
